intro: Matelea corniculata, commonly known as the horned mallow, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its distinctive, horn-shaped bracts that surround the flowers, giving it its common name. It produces showy, pink to purple flowers that bloom in the spring. The leaves are palmately lobed and often have a fuzzy texture, contributing to its ornamental value in gardens.
